story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe National Creative Project has been created by the charity Blind Veterans UKto keep veterans connected and to prevent them from feeling isolated during the lockdown period.The project focuses on creative activities and allows their veterans to get involved with dferent hobbies such as gardening and woodwork, from the comfort and safety of their own home.Lewis Evans, ,has been involved with the painting for beginners and improvers project.Lewis Evans has been joining other veterans virtually to get involved with painting during the lockdown period He said: ldquoIrsquove always had an interest in art and craft and actually wanted to become an art teacher when I was younger."I submitted a painting for the charityrsquos Exhibition Fundraiser last year and it sold for pound!"It was after this that I heard about the National Creative Project, so I decided to get involved.He served in the Welsh Guards for  years and was discharged as a Major in . He has been diagnosed with Wet Macular Degeneration and only has about % vision in his right eye.Fortunately, Mr Evansfound Blind Veterans UK and he started to receive support from the charity in .ldquoBlind Veterans UK have given me a new le. Irsquove been to the charityrsquos Llandudno centre many times and met other veterans," added Mr Evans."Irsquove been part of the choir and I even sang for the other veterans during a coffee break once! I want to help the charity in any way I can.Mr Evans has created many dferent paintings with pastels and watercolours. He has also created ink and pencil drawings.One of Mr Evans paintings ldquoAs part of the project, the charity sent me four dferent pictures of landscapes along with the equipment Irsquod need to recreate the picture," he said.MORE NEWS:"You can either copy those designs or create your own. I have created lots of dferent paintings with animals and some with winter themes. I have also painted a mountain scene of North Wales."Mr Evans panting of a fruit bowl Dave Bryant, Art and Craft Instructor at Blind Veterans UK, said:ldquoThe Painting for Beginners and Improvers project has been designed for members of all abilities to enjoy art."Members may choose to use their own materials or receive materials and equipment as part of their pack."The NCP has allowed us to reconnect with members, such as Lewis, in a new and exciting way. The project has given members a new purpose and something to look forward to."The painting group have monthly calls so the veterans can check in with each other and see how each other are getting on. This has been a great support for those who would have otherwise felt isolated during the lockdown period.ldquoI am going to join my first call next week," added Mr Evans."Itrsquoll be nice to be able to speak to others who are doing the painting project. Painting has been great for me during lockdown."I live on my own and I donrsquot like going out walking too much because of the virus. title: dyffryn gardens joins cerys matthews backing plant health campaign
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe physical and mental health benefits of planting and growing are well understood, and as spring approaches our thoughts turn to our precious gardens, as people across Wales make their planting plans and purchases for the growing season ahead.Plant enthusiast and famous singer, songwriter, author and broadcaster Cerys Matthews is backing a Welsh Government campaign to offer advice and guidance to enhance our enjoyment of the garden, by sourcing plants carefully, inspecting them on arrival to detect and control the spread of pests and diseases, and adopting good husbandry practices.Cerys is passionate about the countryside, and created the Good Le Experience festival of culture and the great outdoors in North Wales.Cerys Matthews She said: ldquoI adore plants, I talk to them and play music to them. They are just so vitally important, providing the oxygen we breathe and the food we eat, and bring le to our iconic countryside."We need to look after plants and keep them healthy and free of plant pests and diseases.With garden centres in Wales currently closed and buyers sourcing online, the campaignrsquos key plant biosecurity messages are:Buy plants from knowledgeable suppliers who you can ask where the plant was sourced from, how to care for it, and what plant pests and diseases it might be prone to.Seek advice from Walesrsquo excellent network of independent, knowledgeable garden centres and retailers.Regularly clean your garden tools and footwear to stop the spread of invasive plants, plant pests or plant diseases.Dispose of unwanted plants and plant material responsibly. Not all plants are suitable for composting. Do not allow invasive plants, plant pests or plant diseases to spread from your land.There are a number of ways you can control plant pests, weeds and diseases. Always consider non-chemical control before using chemical pesticides.     If you do decide to use pesticides, always read the product label carefully before use. This may specy or recommend specic actions for use. Always dispose of unused pesticides and pesticide containers responsibly.MORE NEWS:This Plant Health campaign is being supported by  Plant Health Sentinel Sites across Wales.These are parks and gardens, such as the National Botanic Garden, Bodnant Garden, and Dyffryn Gardens, that are working with our Animal and Plant Health inspectors to act as an early warning system for plant pests and diseases, and promoting good plant health practice to the wider public for the benefit of our wildle, the environment, our culture, well-being and economy.Dyffryn Gardens The network took part this week in a virtual event, which was addressed by Welsh Minister for Environment, Energy and Rural Affairs, Lesley Grfiths MS, a keen gardener herself.The Minister said: ldquoProtecting plants safeguards le, creating the air we breathe and most of the food we eat. We appreciate now, more than ever before, how important our plants, gardens and parks are to our le and wellbeing, and this campaign will promote best practice and help people grow healthy plants.The campaign is also backed by famous Welsh landscape designers the Rich brothers, Gold Medal winners at the RHS Cha Flower Show TV gardening presenter Meinir Gwilym and Medwyn Williams,  times Cha Gold winner for his outstanding vegetables.Further information on non-chemical control may be found on the RHS website https:www.rhs.org.uk advice profile pid.The campaign is also working with Tyfu Cymru, funded by Welsh Government to build the capacity and capability of the Welsh horticulture industry, who are spreading the biosecurity message amongst the commercial sector, raising awareness of the real threats of plant pests and diseases like Xyllela, a destructive plant pathogen best known for its effect on Italian olive trees. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff vale health board fourth mass vaccination centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe health board currently has three mass vaccination centres - one in Barry, one in Splott, and one in Pentwyn - and will be opening another Cardf-based one towards the end of March.They are working in partnership with Cardf Council and Vale of Glamorgan Council to increase capacity for vaccinations and the new Bayside MVC will enable additional capacity of up to , vaccines per day, which will be dependent on vaccine supply.The new centre is being developed on the former Toys R Us site at the International Sports Village - this site will be accessible for residents in Eastern Vale and people in Cardf.Along with the mass vaccination centres, all  GP practices across the two counties are taking part in the vaccination programme, with community pharmacies set to join the programme from April.Executive Director of Public Health at Cardf and Vale University Health Board, Fiona Kinghorn, said: ldquoThis is the largest vaccination programme the NHS has even been involved in and to date tremendous progress has been made."So far we have vaccinated over a third of our adult population with first doses and some are now receiving their second doses which provides the best protection.ldquoWe are working closely with all of our partners and stakeholders to enable us to deliver the vaccine to as many people as possible as quickly as possible and have been grateful to those that have supported us through this process."Over the next few weeks we anticipate our capacity to increase in line with the new centre and support of our primary care contractors.OTHER NEWS:Volunteers helping deliver injection of hope are praised for their effortsMeet the retired haematologist and the RAF nurse helping the vaccination effortVale Cabinet Member for Health and Social Care, Cllr Ben Gray, said: "More than , vaccinations have now been given in Cardf and the Vale and the collective effort to reach this number has been nothing short of phenomenal.     "The Vale of Glamorgan Council has worked closely with our partners in the health board and Cardf Council to ensure we are able to administer all available vaccine as quickly as possible."This new centre for Cardf and the Vale will allow us to move through the next priority groups even more quickly and bring the end of the pandemic closer still."In addition to the new centre, the health board is also scoping out opportunities to increase local access in the Western Vale of Glamorgan. Discussions are taking place with GP practices in the area and community pharmacies to provide additional vaccination capacity to residents living in this area.To date the Health Board has delivered more than , vaccines with , of these being first doses.Priority Groups - are currently being contacted for their first doses while groups - will start to be contacted for their second doses over the coming months. Music helped me through a dficult time ndash battling with PTSD alone for  years.ldquoMusic and the community were the only things in my le that helped me get through it.Mr Wiltshire setup the station with his partner, Keighly Lewis, and the pair have worked hard to create a  for DJs and artists, also creating online events so they can continue to raise funds for charities.On March , Radio RUER is running an online event with DJs performing over a  hour period, raising money for The Trussel Trust which runs food banks across the UK, including in the Vale.Last year Trussel Trust Food Bank handed out . million food parcels to under privileged and low income families.The event, running from pm to am, will be filmed from Ratio Studios in Merthyr Tydfil and aired across social media - you can find it on Facebook here and you can donate via their GoFundMe page.ldquoThe government said the entertainment industry isnrsquot viable and that artists should retrain, added Mr Wiltshire.ldquoIn my opinion the music industry has been hit the hardest out of all the businesses ndash for many performers this is their only source of income, yet theyrsquore still coming together to make a dference to other peoplersquos lives.ldquoNot only is this raising funds for charities, but they are giving people stuck at home entertainment.You can find Radio RUAR on Facebook @OfficialRUAR article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ty hafan appoints new ceo director income generation
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityT# Hafan has appointed a new chief executive and director of income generation.The charity ndash which provides specialist palliative care services for children and young people across Wales ndash announced that interim chief executive Maria Timon Samra has the job on a permanent basis. She initially took over last May as interim.Phae Jones has also been appointed as permanent director of income generation after taking up the role on an interim basis in October.Phae Jones is Ty Hafans new director of income generation. Picture: Peter MorganT# Hafan board chairman Martin Davies said: ldquoMaria Timon Samra joined T# Hafan as interim chief executive last May. During her tenure she has led the organisation through an unprecedented period of challenge precipitated by the pandemic. She was also the voluntary chairwoman and trustee of T# Hafan between February  and December ldquoThe board has invited Maria to become our chief executive on a substantive basis, and Irsquom very pleased to announce that she has accepted our invitation.Ms Samra said: ldquoGiven my long voluntary association with this special charity, I feel humbled that the board of T# Hafan has entrusted the chief executive role to me. It is a genuine privilege to lead the fantastic team here and to see first-hand the dference they make to children with le limiting conditions, and their families, across Wales.ldquoT# Hafan has faced, and is continuing to face, immense financial challenges as a result of the pandemic, not in the least because of the cessation of all in-person fundraising events and the closureof our  shops due to the lockdown. This leaves us with a predicted income shortfall of approximately pound million for the coming year.ldquoT# Hafanrsquos inspirational care team has also had to adapt the way they deliver services, working incredibly hard to keep our hospice in Sully open for crisis stays and end-of-le care, and delivering care and support virtually to the hundreds of children and their families whom we support in their communities throughout Wales.     ldquoIt has been an enormous privilege for me to work with this team for the past  months as an interim chief executive, and I am very excited to continue to work with them on a permanent basis."I am committed to ensuring we are able to deliver the highest quality care and support to those who need our services throughout Wales, and excited to build on the proud heritage of T# Hafan. I am confident that with the continued generous support of the people of Wales, we will build back better after the pandemic.Phae Jones joins as director of income generation on a permanent basis. She joined T# Hafan in July  on the legacy project but was appointed as interim director of income generation that October. She has  years experience of fundraising in the charity sector and six years in commercialbusinessdevelopment.Some of Ms Jonesrsquo previous roles include head of fundraising for the Wye and Usk Foundation and has held senior roles in Worldwide Cancer Research and the Royal National Leboat Institution.The University of South Wales alumni also led a critical incident team during the London bombings in .Ms Jones has been spearheading the lsquofit for futurersquo campaign to raise pound million to refurbish the hospice in Sully.Ms Samra said of Ms Jones: ldquoSince joining us on July  last year Phae has had a great impact, supporting us to rebuild and transform our income generation capability. A true professions and team player, Phae is collaborating to ensure that T# Hafanrsquos fundraising and philanthropic activities are supporter-led and data driven, and our income generation colleagues have the training and support they need.Maria Timon Samra is Ty Hafans new CEOldquoT# Hafan is very fortunate to have secured the benefit of Phaersquos extensive experience and expertise, and her positive, caring, collaborative, lsquocan-dorsquo approach.Ms Jones said of her appointment: ldquoI feel so privileged to be leading T# Hafanrsquos income generation team. T# Hafan is all about Wales and itrsquos about harnessing that passion.ldquoOur lsquofit for the futurersquo refurbishment appeal to upgrade our hospice is probably T# Hafanrsquos biggest single fundraising appeal since it was founded  years ago.ldquoIf yoursquod said to me, at the beginning of , letrsquos run an appeal for pound million for capital spend, in the midst of a pandemic, Irsquod have said lsquono thank you very much indeed!rsquo But we have so very nearly done it, with just around pound, left to go.ldquoFor us to have been able to do this is a testament to the incredible generosity of the people of Wales, and to the hard work of T# Hafanrsquos fundraising teams.ldquoFor me now, itrsquos all about raising the funds we need to reach all those children, young people and their families who need our support, enabling them to live their fullest lives possible, and adapting T# Hafanrsquos services to meet the needs of families as fully and effectively as we can.To find out more about T# Hafan visitwww.tyhafan.org. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: dinas powys bypass plans move one step closer
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe new road would be built from the Merrie Harrier junction on Cardf Road, around the east of Dinas Powys, rejoining Cardf Road just south of Green Lane.Transport planners are hoping the bypass would reduce congestion in the village and make it easier to travel from Barry to Cardf.Consultants hired by the Vale of Glamorgan council have looked in detail at an outline business case for the bypass, including ious options, and a three-month public consultation is expected to start later this year.Arcadis Consulting recommended building the bypass, improving public transport in the area, and making it safer to walk and cycle. They saidmore drivers used the bypass instead of driving through Dinas, the village would be safer for pedestrians and cyclists.Bypass plansThe Arcadis report is going to the Vale cabinet on Monday, March . Community councillors in Dinas Powys had previously complained about the long delays in publishing the report.The road will likely cost about pound million. No funding has been secured yet from the Welsh Government. But the next stage, pending a successful public consultation, would be for the consultants to write up a full business case and for the Vale council to bid for the funding.MORE NEWS:One option includes building a roundabout halfway down the bypass, linking it with Murch Road.Arcadis highlighted several problems with the existing transport infrastructure between Barry and Cardf, including overcrowding rush-hour trains and buses lack of safe walking and cycling routes congestion car accidents and air and noise pollution.They added that new housing developments in the area would likely increase the pressure on the roads and public transport.     The report to cabinet said: ldquoIf a bypass is delivered, the existing adverse impact of road traffic, specically through Dinas Powys, could be reduced.ldquoThe journey time and capacity improvements from the bypass would assist public transport and walking and cycling movements through and within Dinas Powys by reducing general traffic volumes.The bypass could also help congestion, journey times, air quality, noise pollution, road safety, and better pedestrian crossings within the village.Cycling routes in the area could also soon be improved. The Vale council is planning to work with Cardf and Newport councils in the coming months on a region-wide cycle network. The Vale is also planning to bring electric Nextbikes to Dinas Powys soon, similar to in Penarth. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... Anna put me at ease and it was just like chatting to a friend. I waffle a lot anyway, so it was quite easy for me!ldquoI fostered babies for  years, from birth to adoption, so having seen that side of the coin I realised there were a lot of families out there in need and I wondered how they managed.ldquoBecause of Covid or people losing their jobs, there are now an awful lot more people out there who need us. Itrsquos more important now than ever.ldquoItrsquos crucial to shine a light on the fact we are out there helping families and need support to carry on. Hopefully this podcast can do that.ldquoPeople donrsquot like admitting they need help. But it is important that people are aware they can reach out ndash we want to help people.Ahead of Motherrsquos Day on Sunday, each episode of the It Takes A Village podcast focuses on dferent themes around motherhood such as supporting your mental and physical health, providing essential items for your child or dealing with grief and pain.     And Hilaryrsquos episode ndash which also featured London-based charity Little Village ndash centred on the importance of baby banks and how struggling families can access support for their children.The mini-series is hosted by Celebs Go Dating star Anna, who has also worked on major national programmes and is a published author, qualied counsellor and ambassador for several charities.Cwtch, which became Walesrsquo first baby bank when it was formed in spring , accept donations of excellent-condition, pre-loved items before passing them on to families who have been referred via support agencies.Powered by National Lottery funding, the project has helped more than , families and continued to provide a vital support network throughout the pandemic.Cwtch, whose distribution centre is in Taffrsquos Well, have set up an online lsquowish listrsquo to allow donations to continue for those in need and Hilary thanked National Lottery players for enabling the project to thrive.She added: ldquoWithout National Lottery grants, we wouldnrsquot be able to do what we do.ldquoI canrsquot believe how generous people have been over the past year. They are all in dficult situations themselves, but they have still been able to support us, which is amazing.ldquoBefore the pandemic, I was thinking about stepping back but the fact we couldnrsquot have volunteers meant myself and my family had to step up to keep the charity going. It has given me a new lease of le and I donrsquot think I can step back just yet.National Lottery players raise pound million a week for good causes. National Lottery funding to support the UK-wide response to the coronavirus pandemic has exceeded pound billion during the last year.To find out more about how to access extra support at this time, listen to lsquoIt Takes A Villagersquo now via lotterygoodcauses.org.uk, Spoty or on Apple Podcasts article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: morgans wings helps people affected miscarriages
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIn , Jude Davies and her husband Geoff went to the Early Pregnancy Assessment Unitconcerned that she was bleeding at five weeks pregnant.A scan revealed a strong heartbeat, which put the couplersquos mind at ease.The six week scan showed a strong heartbeatJust four days before Christmas, , the situation escalated and Mrs Davies, from Cardf, went to AE.ldquoI started shaking and crying, said Mrs Davies.ldquoI apologised to my husband as I felt guilty, like somehow this was my fault."She was booked in for a scan on Friday, December .ldquoA few days later, I had been having contractions throughout the day and I suddenly became really hot," said the -year-old.ldquoThe pain seemed to stop, but the bleeding didnt - I knew Id lost the baby."Mrs Davies was taken into AE while drting in and out of consciousness and rushed to resus with dangerously low blood pressure. She was later told she had likely miscarried.ldquoI tried to put a brave face on, said Mrs Davies.ldquoIt was so hard. I kept thinking of everything that had happened - we had gone from excitement and looking forward to the future to absolute heartbreak.ldquoI felt angry as everything around us carried on. Christmas came, the children laughed, everyone  seemed to enjoying themselves and all I wanted to do was curl up in a ball and ignore it all.Jude and Geoff DaviesFurther heartache followed at her EPAU appointment on December , . The baby - who the couple planned to call Morgan - had stopped growing but a manual extraction was needed.ldquoMy world came crashing down around me again, said Ms Davies.ldquoI felt numb, overwhelmed, sick and just incredibly sad and confused.Mrs Davies said she was given a phone number for a bereavement nurse, but that she felt she needed more support.     ldquoBecause this happened before  weeks, we donrsquot have a birth certicate or death certicate ndash therersquos nothing to say baby Morgan ever existed except for that six-week scan," said Mrs Davies.ldquoI think often society thinks a miscarriage is trivial, but I have found it so hard.ldquoI grieve for the loss of my babies and the hopes and dreams we had. We havenrsquot just lost a baby we lost the future we saw ourselves having.Following the tragedy Jude and Geoff set up a not-for-profit group to help others which has now been established for just over a year.Morgans Wings has donated care packages to Royal Gwent Hospital in Newport and Nevill Hall Hospital in Abergavenny. In future the group will donate to Grange Hospital in Cwmbran.Morgans Wings care packagesMorgans Wings also offers remembrance boxes on a UK-wide basis and certicates of le which can be sent worldwide."Weve had a really good response," said Mrs Davies."Its a mixture of emotions because the people who come to us have sadly suffered a miscarriage, but Im also quite proud to offer this support."We just want people to know that support is out there."Jude and Geoff Davies, along with some friends, are currently undertaking a sponsored marathon throughout March to raise money for Morgans Wings. Their JustGiving page is available here.They are aiming to raise at least pound to help people affected by miscarriage by providing hygiene packages and memory boxes.Find Morgans Wings on Facebook @MorgansWings or visit their website at morgans-wings article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale vaccination centres benefit red cross volunteers
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe volunteers have been supporting the roll-out of the vaccines in the region since mid-January in partnership with St John Ambulance Cymru ndash putting in almost  shts.They have been at the Barry, Pentwyn and University Hospital Llandough centres, providing a warm welcome and making sure that people are able to find their way around the centre and have the information they need before receiving the vaccine, allowing the clinical staff to focus on the administering of the vaccinations.The St Johnrsquos volunteers sit with the people after having their vaccination ndash being first aid trained, they are able to make sure there are no adverse reactions, that the person is okay and are able to identy and administer first aida reaction does occur.Lynne Cronin is one of the NHS team working on the rollout for the health board and has found the volunteers to be extremely helpful.She said: ldquoAt the beginning we didnrsquot always have volunteers every day. That meant we had to release our own staff to do the meet and greet part. It depleted the number of clinicians. Having volunteers means that doesnrsquot slow us down. We couldnrsquot operate without them now.Katie Cooke, , and Jess Daly, , both from Cardf, are two of the volunteers at the centres.MORE NEWS:Ms Cooke said: ldquoIrsquove had lots of nice chats with people. Some of them are actually quite emotional about getting vaccinated. Many had barely been outside for the better part of a year. They talk about it being a privilege ndash about feeling really lucky. Itrsquos been quite interesting seeing the impact the vaccine is having on people, how it makes them feel somewhat safer.     Ms Day said: ldquoIrsquom thrilled to be volunteering, delighted. It feels really good to be part of a national effort and to be able to do something to contribute ndash Irsquom really excited about that. Itrsquos really satisfying to know that we are supporting an important part of the vaccination process.ldquoAt the vaccination centre, everyone has been incredibly welcoming. The staff were very busy but really appreciative of having volunteers there which was nice.ldquoIrsquom volunteering to make sure that meet and greet tasks get done so that highly trained skilled people can focus on the tasks that need their skills and their training, and they donrsquot need to marshal the queue or tell people where to sit.ldquoNHS staff can focus on what they need to do, they are really appreciative of our support, so it works well for everyone. Itrsquos been great feeling like Irsquom doing something useful.St John Ambulance Cymru, Cardf volunteer Claire Stone said: ldquoItrsquos been an absolute privilege to be a part of Walesrsquo vaccination programme. Everything has gone smoothly so far and wersquore looking forward to continuing our ongoing support of the programme across the coming weeks and months."Irsquove loved working alongside volunteers at the British Red Cross. Itrsquos been great seeing such a combined effort going towards supporting this vital programme. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: make events cymru year closures due coronavirus
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityOn  March , the UK government called for drastic action to halt the spread of coronavirus. Boris Johnson advised public buildings, including theatres, to close and mass gatherings to stop.This week,  months on, campaign group We Make Events Cymru, reflects on the impact of Covid- and how the lockdown restrictions has had a devastating effect on their industry.The impact of the announcement back in March last year meant that the UK event sector came to an outright standstill, resulting in events being cancelled, theatre and music shows could not be staged and thousands of Welsh event professionals could not work.We Make Events Cymru, , has spent the last  months lobbying the Welsh Government to highlight the need for continued sector support in order for the events organisers, iniduals and supply chain to survive Covid- restrictions.After a year of campaigning, We Make Events Cymru continues to push for opportunities to re-open the sector in light of the Welsh Government Coronavirus Control Plan , which does not allow gatherings of more than  people in Tier .As a result of many conversations with the Welsh Government, We Make Events Cymru has created a survey to gather the much needed data to evidence the number of people involved in the sector and the contribution they make to Wales and its economy.Stephen Burkitt-Harrington, Director of Production  one of Walesrsquo leading Creative Events Companies, said: ldquoThe Welsh Government has been saying all along that it could not reopen events of any kind without industry specic data. We were surprised to learn that they were not collecting this information though."This is why we have put together the biggest survey of our industry ever undertaken in Wales. Companies big and small, venues, events, and every inidual involved in even the smallest way can contribute now."By giving us as little or as much as people are prepared to contribute, we can then provide the government with the much talked about data they say they need to see how valuable our wide ranging industry is to the Welsh economy, and how important it is to get it open again as soon as it is safe to.Alongside the survey, the group have also recently launched their own website which gives sector colleagues access to wellbeing and financial advice, access to a database of Welsh event organisers, suppliers and iniduals, as well as a forum to chat and exchange ideas ndash resources that the team believe is vitally important during the pandemic.MORE NEWS:We Make Events Cymru is in regular dialogue with Welsh Government to lobby, and is part of the working party preparing for Covid-safe outdoor and indoor test events. These test events are an integral stepping-stone to get the industry in Wales back working again .Sarah Hemsley-Cole, Director of Cardf based SC Productions and the Lead Coordinator for the campaign said: ldquoWhilst we have to accept large mass gatherings are not possible in  ndash it is essential that we keep up the pressure on Welsh Government to allow covid safe cultural activities in the Summer of ."We are a creative and innovative sector, and by working with Welsh Government to develop appropriate guidance and to generate factual data and evidence from the test events, we can get performers, artists, technicians and the eco system back to work and audiences back to what they love.Working alongside partners such as Equity, Creu Cymru, BECTU, Cardf Music Board, Cult Cymru, Freelancers Make Theatre Work Freelances Task Force, What About Weddings and The Musicians Union ndash We Make Events Cymru has helped give the industry and events people a crucial voice during these unprecedented times.Following on from the recent budget announcement, We Make Events Cymru acknowledge the essential package of support already received from the UK and Welsh governments, and is pleased to hear of the further support expected with the extension of furlough, additional SEISS grants ndash which now includes newcomers to the industry who started their businesses in the   tax year, as well as the Cultural Recovery Fund.We Make Events Cymru are now waiting to hear about additional financial aid and get a better understanding of how long this relief money is expected to last business and iniduals in Wales. There are still thousands across the country who have been excluded from any kind of financial support ndash these people need to be recognised and also offered funding.The campaign group is also calling for the events industry to be considered on a par with other industries like hospitality and the Film and TV sector for things such as insurance and financial schemes.The UK is internationally recognised for delivering impressive cultural events. Within it, Wales plays a signicant role with its tremendous highly skilled workforce, many of whom have now had to ersy to work in other jobs.The impact of the lockdown will be felt within the Welsh events industry for many years to come. Rhys Maule, Managing Director of ProLX Productions in Cwmbran said: ldquoThe loss of extremely talented, hard working and dedicated professionals is really hard to see."These people are being backed into a corner as a result of no support and canrsquot see any way out other than to change career and move onto something more secure. Lots of these people feel they may neveras the risk is too great, which is devastating, and the impact on their metal health as a result of this is hard to hear.He added ldquoThe huge number of people falling through the gaps not receiving funding is something that needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency to ensure the future of our industry.The COVID- pandemic has caused many events around Wales and the UK to be cancelled or postponed due the government-imposed restrictions on large gatherings. Among the most prominent events to be affected in Wales in  have been the National Eisteddfod, the Royal Welsh Show, Hay Festival, Abergavenny Food Festival, Cardf Half Marathon, Llangollen International Eisteddfod, Green Man and Ironman. Many of these have also been postponed for .In August  event organisations from across the UK joined forces to bring attention to the critical condition of the live events industry by lighting venues and iconic buildings in red. Wales Millennium Centre, Motorpoint Arena Cardf, Pontio,Venue Cymru and Aberystwyth Arts Centre were just some of the venues that lent their support to the campaign.We Make Events Cymru is calling on anyone who contributes to events in Wales and its eco-system to complete the survey in order to evidence the valuable contribution the sector makes in Wales.For more information about the survey, visit: https:www.wemakeevents.cymru . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: griffin books win wales independent bookshop year
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIn Wales, theIndependent Bookshop of the Yeargoes to PenarthsGrfin Booksmdashwho hit national news praised for their flexible approach during lockdowns including remote working.Grfin Books of Penarth, opened in . The judges praised owner Mel Grfin and her teamrsquos adaptability, with its flexible approach during lockdowns including remote working, ersying its distribution when book supply became dficult and, during the Welsh October firebreak, negotiating with a neighbouring essential shopto become a collection point in order to maintain its high street presence.Owner, Mel Grfin said: "It really does mean the world to the whole team for our small shop to be recognised in this way."Weve been overwhelmed by the support and kind words weve received from the local community over the last year and we cant thank everyone enough."The British Book Awards or Nibbies has been the leading awards for the book trade since .Celebrating the best books, the best bookshops and the best publishers it is supported by all major industry associations including The Publishers Association, The Booksellers Association and the Independent Publishers Guild. Judged by leading industry experts it is regarded as lsquothe BAFTAs of the book tradersquo.MORE NEWS:Tom Tivnan, The Booksellerrsquos managing editor and chair of the Independent Bookshop of the Year judging , said: ldquoThis was certainly the most dficult year of judging this award in Nibbies history and not because the pandemic was a body blow to indies."Far from it,though booksellers obviously would not have chosen the conditions of , we were inundated with some of the strongest submissions we have ever seen.     "Across Britain and Ireland indie booksellers not just survived but thrived in the past yearmdashdealing with the ious lockdowns by nimbly pivoting their business models with creativity and flair. ldquoThe most interesting thing was that while many of the shops moved to being online booksellers during lockdown periods, they did so while maintaining their identity, their support for their core customers and their links to local communities, perhaps proving that bookseller know-how and expertise will beat an algorithm any day.The Nibbies virtual ceremony will be held on th May. title: new food vale festival help local businesses post covid
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe inaugural Food Vale Festival will take place from Monday, March to Sunday, April ,  and will include a series of virtual events designed to bring people closer to food producers and businesses in the Vale, whilehighlighting opportunities to improve the local food system, post-Covid .The festival is being organised by Food Vale, part of the Sustainable Food Places network - a partnership programme led by the Soil Association, Food Matters and Sustain: the alliance for better food and farming.Food Vale aims to help to build a more sustainable local food system and improve the access, affordability and availability of good food across the Vale of Glamorgan.Louise Denham is the festival organiser and Sustainable Food Places co-ordinator at Food Vale. She explained:Louise Denham of Food ValeldquoThe last  months have been a really challenging time for everyone iniduals, families, food producers, and food business owners right across the Vale of Glamorgan.ldquoBut there now seems to be a real appetite to build back better after Covid-, and to create a thriving, local food system which celebrates the unique character of the Vale and connects its communities.ldquoThe Food Vale Festival aims to celebrate this local groundswell in support for a more connected county, whilst highlighting Food Valersquos three key aims to ensure a good meal for everybody every day to support local food businesses to thrive and to connect local and global food opportunities.The festival has received funding through the Vale of Glamorgan Council and Welsh Government Rural Communities ndash Rural Development Programme -, which is funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the Welsh Government.MORE NEWS:The Food Vale Festival Programme:Online cook-along events form a signicant part of the Food Vale festival programme, all of which will be available for free, via the Food Vale Facebook page. Richard Shaw fromCooking Together will provide a number of demonstrations suitable for the whole family, with recipes including a Friday Night Curry, Fruit Muffins, and even an Easter Egg Pizza.Amy Greenfield from Awesome.Wales - the Valersquos first zero waste store - will host a takeover of the Food Vale Twitter account, sharing her expertise on how to reduce waste in the home.There will be a virtual tour of Barryrsquos Community Garden, Gibby Green Fingers.Traders from Cowbridge Farmers Market will also take part in a Twitter takeover later in the festival programme.Three new films have also been created to showcase some of the sustainable food businesses in the local area Cobbles Kitchen and Deli and Forage Farm Shop are both featured. The films will be shared on Food Valersquos social media channels throughout the festival period.The third film will feature Cadogs Corner, a community cafeacute which uses donated FareShare food to provide wholesome meals and provide cooking workshops and food parcels for vulnerable families.It was set up by parents and staff at Cadoxton Primary School to address isolation and food poverty, while offering opportunities for pupils and parents to learn new skills like cooking andfoodhygiene.Natasha Cockram, who runs Cadogs Corner, said:Natasha Cockram, Cadogs CornerldquoWe are thrilled to be part of the Food Vale festival, highlighting the importance of everyone having access to good food.For us, itrsquos also great to be able to show how communities in the Vale can work together to support each other in times of need.To find out more about the Food Vale Festival, visit: foodvale.org food-vale-festival and join the Facebook event to receive notications about the free cook-along dates.Get involved on social media by using the hashtags #FoodValeFest and #GwylBwydYFro. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: further analysis needed vale road linking a m
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe road would link Sycamore Cross on the A with Junction  of the M. A -week public consultation last year raised concerns about the impact on the environment and local communities.Responding to those concerns, the Vale of Glamorgan council has now said transport planners must analyse further how the road would fit in with the new context of Covid- and the climate emergency.In a report to the councilrsquos cabinet, which meets on Monday, March , detailed responses were given to the main concerns raised in the consultation. The cabinet will be asked to approve further analysis, before moving on to writing up a full business case for the road.The case for the road is to improve transport across the region, including to Cardf Airport, St Athanrsquos Enterprise Zone, and new housing developments. It would likely cost around pound million to build, and is dependent on funding from the Welsh Government.However, the proposals have drawn criticism from villagers in Pendoylan whose houses would be knocked down, cyclists using country lanes which could be blocked off, and Coed Cymru which has warned ancient woodland would be felled to make way for the road.Two options for the new road were consulted on: one to the east of Pendoylan and one to the west. The report revealed transport planners are edging towards the western route, as it is better value for money than the eastern one.As well as suggesting further analysis, the cabinet report addressed the main concerns including the impact on the climate, environment, walkers and cyclists, and uncertain future of the financially struggling Cardf Airport.On cycling, the new road would include a segregated lsquoactive travel routersquo for cyclists and walkers, the report said. Country lanes blocked off could have bridges or underpasses for walkers and cyclists to cross the new road.     MORE NEWS:The report said: ldquoThere is currently poor infrastructure and local connectivity by walking and cycling through the study area, and there is potential to implement new cycle connections. An active travel route is an integral component of the concept options.ldquoShould a preferred option progress to the next stage of assessment and a need to block the lanes confirmed, access for non-motorised users to safely cross under or over the bypass would be accommodated as part of the design.On climate change, campaigners raised concerns a new road would increase private car journeys and carbon emissions.Both the Welsh Government and the Vale council declared a climate emergency in , pledging to reduce carbon emissions in an effort to prevent catastrophic increases in global temperatures.A big part of the plan to reduce emissions in Wales is changing how people travel: fewer journeys in private cars and more by walking, cycling and in public transport.The report said further analysis would include a lsquocarbon assessment and climate resiliencersquo report, and would explore how to reduce the carbon impact of the road.It did not mention what these methods could include.Several areas of ancient woodland would have ldquovery large adverse impacts according to the report. But further assessment would examine the exact effects of the loss of that woodland.The report said: ldquoThe environmental assessment would examine the loss of woodland in terms of its use in flood retention, water quality, social value, carbon capture, landscape value and cultural heritage value, as well as its value to bioersity.If the ldquovery large adverse impacts canrsquot be avoided by redesigning the road, new trees could be planted where to compensate for the loss of ancient woodland.This would include moving and replanting some of the old trees and soil.The next stage would also include a wider, detailed environmental impact assessment, and recommendations on how to mitigate potential impacts on the environment surrounding the proposed road.Another concern raised has been the uncertain future of Cardf Airport, which was recently bailed out by the Welsh Government with a pound. million grant.But transport planners pointed to plans to make it easier to get to the airport on foot, by bike, bus, train, and in private motor vehicles.The cabinet report said: ldquoWhile recognising that the basis of future studies would increasingly need to consider the emerging trends and patterns resulting from Covid-, it is understood that the long-term vision of the airport remains at this present time.Responding to the report, campaigners have renewed calls for the Vale council to scrap the plans for the road altogether.A spokesperson for Vale Communities for Future Generations said: ldquoWhy the Vale of Glamorgan council is persisting in wasting public money on keeping this outdated road plan alive is hard to understand. The sheer volume of recent objections to the proposal clearly indicates the public has other priorities.ldquoThe original  Vale council assumption was that the road was needed for better vehicle access to Cardf Airport mdash which was denied by the airport management.ldquoSince then the airportrsquos passenger numbers have shrunk, millions of pounds of public money has been spent by the Welsh Government on propping it up financially and the future of air travel globally is uncertain post Covid  pandemic.ldquoThese are hardly the circumstances under which to continue promoting an expensive and environmentally destructive road building plan that was developed before the Vale of Glamorgan council and the Welsh Government declared a climate emergency in .ldquoIt is time for this plan to be recognised as a prime example of outdated thinking, and finally scrapped so that Vale of Glamorgan council can prioritise spending on environmentally sound projects. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: nicola sturgeon not breach ministerial code independent report concludes
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. QC and challenged her political rivals to respect his verdict.The Conservatives, however, insisted that she was not ldquofree and clear despite Mr Hamilton stating the First Minister ldquodid not breach the provisions of the ministerial code.Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross hit out: ldquoThis report does not change the overwhelming evidence that Nicola Sturgeon misled Parliament, her government badly let women down and wasted more than pound, of taxpayersrsquo money.The former first minister was awarded more than pound, when the Court of Session in Edinburgh ruled the Scottish Government had acted unlawfully in the way it handledharassment allegations made by two women.Ms Sturgeon again apologised to them for the way they had been ldquolet down by the Scottish Government.She said: ldquoI want, once again, to remind people that at the heart of this case were women who had the courage to come forward and complain.Mr Hamilton, a former director of public prosecutions in the Republic of Ireland, is the independent adviser the Scottish Government on the ministerial code, a set of rules about how ministers should conduct themselves.After his findings were published Ms Sturgeon said she was ldquohappy that his reportrsquos findings clear me of any breach of the ministerial code.The First Minister insisted: ldquoI sought at every stage in this issue to act with integrity and in the public interest.ldquoAs I have previously made clear, I did not consider that I had broken the code, but these findings are official, definitive and independent adjudication of that.And she added: ldquoPrior to its publication, opposition politicians stressed the importance of respecting and accepting the outcome of Mr Hamiltonrsquos independent inquiry, and I committed wholeheartedly to doing so.     ldquoNow that he has reported, it is incumbent on them to do likewise.Ms Sturgeon had insisted to Parliament that she only became aware of the allegations against her predecessor in a meeting at her Glasgow home on April  .For months @NicolaSturgeon# has faced a barrage of abuse. Our First Minister has acted with dignity, focused on tackling Covid and always accepted our failure to protect women who made complaints. The words below from the Independent Inquiry are a complete vindication of her. pic xYpdwajUzmdash John SwinneyMarch , Mr Hamilton said that by failing to mention a meeting she had with his former chief of staff Geoff Aberdein just days earlier, on March , which she later said she ldquoforgot the First Minister had given an ldquoincomplete narrative of events.But he added: ldquoI accept that this omission was the result of a genuine failure of recollection and was not deliberate.ldquoThat failure did not therefore in my opinion amount to a breach of the ministerial code.Regarding claims she failed to comply with Scottish Government legal advice to the former first ministerrsquos civil action, Mr Hamilton said she did not break the code.Ms Sturgeon said she welcomed the ldquocomprehensive, evidence-based and unequivocal conclusion.Ms Sturgeon hadreferred herself to the independent adviser on the ministerial code following Mr Salmondrsquos successful legal challenge.Mr Hamiltonrsquos investigation was paused in early  to avoid prejudicing criminal proceedings brought against Mr Salmond.He was acquitted of  charges, including sexual assault, indecent assault and attempted rape, in March  following a High Court trial and Mr Hamiltonrsquos inquiry was delayed again by the pandemic, before resuming in August .A planned no-confidence vote Ms Sturgeonis now likely to fail after the Scottish Greens said they will not support it, saying theTories have shown ldquothey have no interest in establishing the truth, in lodging it before the report was published.But Mr Ross insisted he could not agree with Mr Hamiltonrsquos assessment.I respect this judgement but we cannot agree that the First Minister suddenly turned forgetful.It is up to Parliament to decideshe has been misleading, as James Hamilton says.This report does not change the overwhelming evidence against Nicola Sturgeon.Full statement # pic WMYdgyGqmdash Douglas Ross MPMarch , The Conservative MP said: ldquoThe First Minister has been given a pass because it has been judged her lsquofailure of recollectionrsquo was lsquonot deliberatersquo.ldquoI respect Mr Hamilton and his judgment but we cannot agree with that assessment.ldquoNicola Sturgeon did not suddenly turn forgetful.He added: ldquoAs James Hamilton says, it is up to the Scottish Parliament to decidethe First Minister has been misleading..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Nicola Sturgeon did not breach ministerial code, independent report concludes article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: investigation credible claim identity salmond complainer leaked
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe independent adviser to the Scottish Government on the ministerial code, James Hamilton, cleared the First Minister of any breaches over her involvement in the unlawful investigation of sexual harassment complaints about the former first minister.But he asserted that the claim Mr Salmondrsquos former chief of staff Geoff Aberdein was told the name of a complainer by a member of the First Ministerrsquos staff in early March was believable.The account from Mr Aberdein was corroborated by four people who gave evidence to the inquiry, Mr Hamilton confirmed.In a heavily redacted section of his report, Mr Hamilton states that Mr Aberdeinrsquos recollection of the meeting was ldquomore straightforward than the ldquorather complicated and ldquoelaborate account of the government official who appears to have denied leaking the name. vw,vw,px, px"First Minister Nicola Sturgeon after being cleared of breaching the ministerial code by James Hamilton Mr Aberdein subsequently informed Mr Salmond and three other people about the womanrsquos identity being disclosed ndash former civil servant Lorraine Kay, who worked in the former first ministerrsquos office, former SNP MSP Duncan Hamilton and the SNPrsquos former communications director, Kevin Pringle.Although he acknowledged he cannot be ldquocompletely certain about whose account is truthful, Mr Hamilton concludes: ldquoIn view of the fact that Mr Aberdein informed these four iniduals of the conversation promptly, I believe that Mr Aberdeinrsquos account of what was said by [Redacted] the existence of complaints and the identity of a complainer is credible.When asked about the claim during her evidence session of the separate Holyrood inquiry, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe account that I have been given has given me assurance that what is alleged to have happened at that meeting did not happen in the way that has been described.     She suggested that Mr Salmond may have already known the name of one of the complainersldquobecause he had apologised to the person concerned and had possibly discovered the identity of the other ldquothrough his own investigations.Asked about Mr Hamiltonrsquos finding that it was ldquocredible the identity of a complainer was revealed in an interview after the report was published, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI understand there is a complaint thatrsquos been made about that which will be taken forward in the proper way.ldquoLet me, let me be clear about this, Mr. Hamilton has been asked to look at dferent accounts of meetings and discussions, and he has assessed all of that but what Mr Hamilton was being asked to adjudicate on taking all of that into account, is whether or not I have no doubt that the launch of the reduced speed limits will enhance safety for the entire school community."
